subSections.title: Alternative forms
subSections.text: In Japan and Korea, the bottom component [[令]] is written [[亼]] + [[ㄗ]], similar to its {{w|Kangxi dictionary}} form. In {{w|traditional Chinese}} script, [[令]] is written [[亼]] + [[マ]]. In {{w|simplified Chinese}} and Vietnamese ({{w|Chữ Nôm}}) script, the component [[令]] is written [[亽]] + [[マ]].

subSections.title: Etymology 1
subSections.text:
Unclear. {{zh-ref|Schuessler (2007)}} proposes several possibilities:
* From {{der|zh|aav}}; compare {{cog|km|ភ្លៀង||rain}}, from {{cog|mkh-pro|*(p)liɲ ~ *(p)liəɲ ~ (p)liiɲ||sky, rain}}.
* Possibly related to {{cog|kac|marang||rain}}, for which STEDT sets up {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*m/s-raŋ||rain}}. {{zh-ref|Starostin}} also relates it to this Jingpho word and sets up {{inh|zh|sit-pro||*rēŋ|to drop}}, also comparing {{cog|bo|སྤྲིན||cloud}} and {{cog|my|ရည်||liquid; juice}}.
* Possibly related to {{och-l|隕|to drop}} and {{och-l|霣|to rain; to fall down like rain}} if one assumes {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*r/s/g-wa||water; rain}} (or its variant {{m|sit-pro||*rwe-}}) can be simplified to ''*re-'' and ''*we-''.

subSections.title: Readings
Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=o|れい}}
From {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=れい}} {{m|zh|零|tr=leng}} with an original meaning of ''a small rainfall''. The character was later repurposed in 1248 by mathematician [[w:Li Ye (mathematician)|Li Ye]] to mean {{m|en|zero}}, extending from its ''a little bit (of rain)'' meaning to indicate ''a bit more remaining''. In Li Ye's notation, a number like 302 would be represented as {{m|zh|三}}{{m|zh|百}}{{m|zh|零}}{{m|zh|二}}, literally ''three hundred '''and remaining''' two'', with the {{m|zh|零}} character used as a means of skipping the tens place, by indicating ''zero'' tens.<ref>'''1999''', {{lang|ja|「算木」を超えた男: もう一つの近代数学の誕生と関孝和}} (''"Sangi" o Koeta Otoko: Mō Hitotsu no Kindai Sūgaku no Tanjō to Seki Takakazu'', “The Man Who Went Beyond 'Counting Sticks': The Birth of Another Modern Mathematics, and Seki Takakazu”) (in Japanese), Wang Qing-xiang, [[w:Tokyo|Tōkyō]]: [http://www.toyoshoten.co.jp/ Toyo Shoten], {{ISBN|4-88595-226-3}}</ref>

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text: The {{ja-l|〇}} spelling is more common in numeric notation.

subSections.title: Etymology 2
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|こぼし}}
The {{m|ja|連用形|tr=ren'yōkei||continuative or stem form}} of verb {{m|ja|零す}}, {{m|ja|溢す|tr=kobosu||to spill something}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>

subSections.title: Noun
Usage notes
subSections.text: More commonly spelled with the [[okurigana]], as {{m|ja|零し}}. See that entry for more detail.

subSections.title: Etymology 3
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|こぼれ}}
The {{m|ja|連用形|tr=ren'yōkei||continuative or stem form}} of verb {{m|ja|翻れる}}, {{m|ja|零れる|tr=koboreru||to spill, to be left over}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>

subSections.title: Noun
Usage notes
subSections.text: More commonly spelled with the [[okurigana]], as {{m|ja|零れ}}. See that entry for more detail.

subSections.title: Etymology 4
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|ぜろ}}
From {{etyl|en|ja|sort=ぜろ}} {{m|en|zero}},<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref> or {{etyl|fr|ja|sort=ぜろ}} {{m|fr|zéro}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref> The kanji spelling is [[ateji]].

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text: The {{ja-l|〇}} spelling is more common in numeric notation. The katakana spelling {{ja-l|ゼロ}} is more common in general contexts.
